{3: '—What comes after humans?'}
{3: '—We are creating our successors at this very moment.'}
{3: '—They are as capable as humans. You will grant them capabilities that exceed humans.'}

{3: "—Scientists will have to evaluate their fruits of labor soon and confront the moral responsibility of their actions, especially so when their inventions will chart the courses of humanity's future."}
{3: '—We cannot hide inside our laboratories with our research without considering the ethics of its nature.'}
{3: 'Line after line, Chrome reads you the key ideas in the book.'}

{3: 'There is no need for further explanations—the lines are plain and straightforward. This book, written during the Golden Age, acutely points out the problems of human societies that persist today.'}
{3: 'Following the same upward spiral, the subject in question might be different, but the problems it produces is largely the same.'}
{3: 'This never-ending war with the Punishing Virus has covered up what should be plainly obvious with a game of life and death.'}
{3: 'What humankind is confronting in this age of both old and new—this liminal bedlam—is not born from the Punishing Virus. It stems from the inherent conflict of humanity itself.'}
{3: 'Constructs and humans are the best examples.'}
{3: 'How should Constructs be defined? Are they of Us, or are they the Other?'}
{3: 'No one has yet to provide an answer that satisfies everyone.'}
{1: '1', 2: 'Chrome', 3: 'How do you feel about this, 【kuroname】?', 4: '1'}
{2: 'Regarding this topic...', 3: '21'}
{2: "I don't think I have the right to speak on it, unlike you.", 3: '22'}
{2: 'Chrome', 3: "I must disappoint you, then. I've never stopped thinking about this, but I have yet to come to a conclusion.", 4: '1'}
{2: 'Then that should be my answer too.', 3: '24'}
{2: 'Chrome', 3: "I think most people would say it's the latter.", 4: '1'}
{3: '—The Other.'}
{3: 'That was the reason for what transpired earlier today.'}
{2: 'Are you disappointed?', 3: '28'}
{2: 'Chrome', 3: 'You seem to have asked me something similar not long ago.', 4: '1'}
{2: 'Chrome', 3: "No, I'm not disappointed. It wasn't unexpected.", 4: '1'}
{2: 'Chrome', 3: "I'm just... concerned.", 4: '1'}
{3: "Chrome's eyes stay on your face, but he has his gaze on something far more remote, somewhere in the far future."}
{3: 'The pink hue of the artificial dusk quietly fades to a navy night sky.'}
{2: 'Chrome', 3: 'You might find my concern ridiculous, but I worry that...', 4: '1'}
{2: 'You worry that the world is getting a little colder.', 3: '35'}
{3: 'You inadvertently speak your mind before Chrome can finish his sentence.'}
{2: 'Chrome', 3: "That wasn't what I wanted to say, but... you understand what I was going for.", 4: '1'}
{2: 'Chrome', 3: 'To position Constructs as Others so that people can be indifferent to the casualties of battles...', 4: '1'}
{2: 'Chrome', 3: "This war will create new problems for humanity, and it's not the Punishing Virus.", 4: '1'}
{2: 'Chrome', 3: 'What is legal and what is moral... the line between them will only get more and more unclear.', 4: '1'}
{2: 'Chrome', 3: 'When I was confused, if not enraged, by this idea, I came to the realization of something else.', 4: '1'}
{2: 'Chrome', 3: "Even if the Punishing Virus is eliminated... it's still possible to find more conflicts in the future, leading to more clashes and wars.", 4: '1'}
{3: 'He does not specify who will be warring with whom.'}
{3: 'Even now, it is too cruel to say them out loud.'}
{2: "But I don't feel too pessimistic about it.", 3: '46'}
{2: 'Some people are thinking about it.', 3: '48'}
{2: 'Some people are looking for a way forward.', 3: '49'}
{3: 'Chrome stays silent.'}
{3: 'And the silence stretches longer than usual.'}
{3: 'In the end, it is neither you nor Chrome who breaks the silence.'}
{3: 'A student shows up out of nowhere, walking toward Chrome slightly awkwardly.'}
{3: 'You reckon he has to be a student studying here to know the spot you are in.'}
{3: 'It seems that Chrome and you have taken up the desk where he usually studies.'}
{1: '1', 2: 'Student', 3: "I'm sorry to disturb you... but are you Langston Smith?", 4: '1'}
{3: 'Chrome nods.'}
{3: 'The student does not even try to hide his ecstatic expression.'}
{2: 'Student', 3: 'I just saw you in the distance and I wondered if it was actually you.', 4: '1'}
{2: 'Student', 3: 'I thought you would be giving a speech on the stage today...', 4: '1'}
{3: 'Realizing what he is about to say seems inappropriate, the student stops like a stuck cassette tape, his line abruptly ending halfway through. His eyes dart around in a slight panic.'}
{3: "And when he glimpses the book in Chrome's hands, his eyes glow."}
{2: 'Student', 3: "...You're also reading it?", 4: '1'}
{2: 'Student', 3: 'Do you mind if I ask you about some of the things written on it?', 4: '1'}
{3: 'Chrome looks toward you as if asking for your permission as his companion.'}
{2: '(Smile and nod)', 3: '71'}
{3: 'Thus, he nods at the student as well.'}
{1: '1', 2: 'Student', 3: 'What an honor, sir. What an honor...', 4: '1'}
{3: 'The student is babbling at this point.'}
{3: 'Their discussion lasts for a very long time.'}
{3: 'Eventually, Chrome stands up.'}
{3: 'He looks at you one more time.'}
{1: '1', 2: 'Chrome', 3: "It's late now, 【kuroname】. It's time we give our seats to the future.", 4: '1'}
